In this article, we observe that even without thenHermitian hypothesis, the $L^p$-cohomology of an arithmetic quotient, for $p$nfinite and sufficiently large, is isomorphic to the ordinary cohomology of itsnreductive Borel-Serre compactification.

We use this to generalize a theorem ofnMumford concerning homogeneous vector bundles, their invariant Chern forms andnthe canonical extensions of the bundles; here, though, we are referring toncanonical extensions to the reductive Borel-Serre compactification of anynarithmetic quotient.
To achieve that, we give a systematic discussion of vectornbundles and Chern classes on stratifiedn

authors: Ruipeng Liu, T. Di Matteo, Thomas Lux
title: True and Apparent Scaling: The Proximity of the Markov-Switchingn  Multifractal Model to Long-Range Dependence
abstract: In this paper, we consider daily financial data of a collection of differentnstock market indices, exchange rates, and interest rates, and we analyze theirnmulti-scaling properties by estimating a simple specification of thenMarkov-switching multifractal model (MSM).

In order to see how well thenestimated models capture the temporal dependence of the data, we estimate andncompare the scaling exponents $H(q)$ (for $q = 1, 2$) for both empirical datanand simulated data of the estimated MSM models.
In most cases the multifractalnmodel appears to generate `apparent long memory in agreement with thenempirical scaling laws.n

authors: S.C. Keller, B.P. Schmidt and M.S Bessell
title: SkyMapper and the Southern Sky Survey - a resource for the southern sky
abstract: SkyMapper is amongst the first of a new generation of dedicated, wide-fieldnsurvey telescopes.
The 1.3m SkyMapper telescope features a 5.7 square degreenfield-of-view Cassegrain imager and will see first light in late 2007.
Thenprimary goal of the facility is to conduct the Southern Sky Survey a sixncolour, six epoch survey of the southern sky.
The survey will providenphotometry for objects between 8th and 23rd magnitude with global photometricnaccuracy of 0.03 magnitudes and astrometry to 50 mas.
This will represent anvaluable scientific resource for the southern sky and in addition provide anbasis for photometric and astrometric calibration of imaging data.n

authors: Guangxiang Su
title: Equivariant symmetric bilinear torsions
abstract: We extend the main result in the previous paper of Zhang and the authornrelating the Milnor-Turaev torsion with the complex valued analytic torsion tonthe equivariant case.n

authors: K. M. Hiremath
title: Prediction of future fifteen solar cycles
abstract: In the previous study (Hiremath 2006a), the solar cycle is modeled as anforced and damped harmonic oscillator and from all the 22 cycles (1755-1996),nlong-term amplitudes, frequencies, phases and decay factor are obtained.
Usingnthese physical parameters of the previous 22 solar cycles and by an {emnautoregressive model}, we predict the amplitude and period of the futurenfifteen solar cycles.
Predicted amplitude of the present solar cycle (23)nmatches very well with the observations.
The period of the present cycle isnfound to be 11.73 years.
With these encouraging results, we also predict thenprofiles of future 15 solar cycles.

Important predictions are : (i) the periodnand amplitude of the cycle 24 are 9.34 years and 110 ($pm 11$), (ii) thenperiod and amplitude of the cycle 25 are 12.49 years and 110 ($pm$ 11), (iii)nduring the cycles 26 (2030-2042 AD), 27 (2042-2054 AD), 34 (2118-2127 AD), 37n(2152-2163 AD) and 38 (2163-2176 AD), the sun might experience a very highnsunspot activity, (iv) the sun might also experience a very low (around 60)nsunspot activity during cycle 31 (2089-2100 AD) and, (v) length of the solarncycles vary from 8.65 yrs for the cycle 33 to maximum of 13.07 yrs for thencycle 35.n

authors: Sandra Rozensztajn (IRMA)
title: Comparaison entre cohomologie cristalline et cohomologie etalen  $p$-adique sur certaines varietes de Shimura
abstract: Let $X$ be an integral model at a prime $p$ of a Shimura variety of PEL typenhaving good reduction, associated to a reductive group $G$.
To $mathbb{Z}_p$nreprsententations of the group $G$ can be associated two kinds of sheaves :ncrystals on the special fiber of $X$, and locally constant etale sheaves onnthe generic fiber.
We establish a comparison between the cohomology of thesentwo kinds of sheaves.n

authors: Herbert Koch and Daniel Tataru
title: Carleman estimates and unique continuation for second order parabolicn  equations with nonsmooth coefficients
abstract: This work is devoted to the strong unique continuation problem for secondnorder parabolic equations with nonsmooth coefficients.
Introduction andnbibliography have been revised.n

authors: S. Tertychniy
title: Specialized computer algebra system for application in generaln  relativity
abstract: A brief characteristic of the specialized computer algebra system GRG_ECnintended for symbolic computations in the field of general relativity is given.n

authors: Stefano Viaggiu
title: Rigidly rotating dust solutions depending upon harmonic functions
abstract: We write down the relevant field equations for a stationary axially symmetricnrigidly rotating dust source in such a way that the general solution dependsnupon the solution of an elliptic equation and upon harmonic functions.
Startingnwith the dipole Bonnor solution, we built an asymptotically flat solution withntwo curvature singularities on the rotational axis with diverging mass.

Apartnfrom the two point singularities on the axis, the metric is regular everywhere.nFinally, we study a non-asymptotically flat solution with NUT charge and anmassless ring singularity, but with a well-defined mass-energy expression.n

authors: Paul Prekop
title: Supporting Knowledge and Expertise Finding within Australias Defencen  Science and Technology Organisation
abstract: This paper reports on work aimed at supporting knowledge and expertisenfinding within a large Research and Development (R&D) organisation.
The papernfirst discusses the nature of knowledge important to R&D organisations andnpresents a prototype information system developed to support knowledge andnexpertise finding.
The paper then discusses a trial of the system within an R&Dnorganisation, the implications and limitations of the trial, and discussesnfuture research questions.n

authors: C.A. Baker, D.D. Doyle, P. Geltenbort, K. Green, M.G.D. van dern  Grinten, P.G. Harris, P. Iaydjiev, S.N. Ivanov, D.J.R. May, J.M. Pendlebury,n  J.D. Richardson, D. Shiers, K.F. Smith
title: Reply to Comment on ``An Improved Experimental Limit on the Electricn  Dipole Moment of the Neutron
abstract: The Authors reply to the Comment of Golub and Lamoreaux.
The experimentalnlimit on the neutron electric dipole moment remains unchanged from thatnpreviously announced.n

authors: Xavier Calmet and Martin Kober
title: Lowest Landau Level of Relativistic Field Theories in a Strongn  Background Field
abstract: We consider gauge theories in a strong external magnetic like field.

Thisnsituation can appear either in conventional four-dimensional theories, but alsonnaturally in extra-dimensional theories and especially in brane world models.nWe show that in the lowest Landau level approximation, some of the coordinatesnbecome non-commutative.

We find physical reasons to formal problems withnnon-commutative gauge theories such as the issue with SU(N) gauge symmetries.nOur construction is applied to a minimal extension of the standard model.
It isnshown that the Higgs sector might be non-commutative whereas the remainingnsectors of the standard model remain commutative.
Signatures of this model atnthe LHC are discussed.

We then discuss an application to a dark matter sectorncoupled to the Higgs sector of the standard model and show that here again,ndark matter could be non-commutative, the standard model fields remainingncommutative.n

authors: Jyh-Shyan Lin, Jen-Chun Chang, Rong-Jaye Chen, Torleiv Kl{o}ve
title: Distance preserving mappings from ternary vectors to permutations
abstract: Distance-preserving mappings (DPMs) are mappings from the set of all q-arynvectors of a fixed length to the set of permutations of the same or longernlength such that every two distinct vectors are mapped to permutations with thensame or even larger Hamming distance than that of the vectors.
In this paper,nwe propose a construction of DPMs from ternary vectors.
The constructed DPMsnimprove the lower bounds on the maximal size of permutation arrays.n

authors: Xavier Calmet
title: Planck Length and Cosmology
abstract: We show that an unification of quantum mechanics and general relativitynimplies that there is a fundamental length in Nature in the sense that nonoperational procedure would be able to measure distances shorter than thenPlanck length.
Furthermore we give an explicit realization of an old proposalnby Anderson and Finkelstein who argued that a fundamental length in naturenimplies unimodular gravity.
Finally, using hand waving arguments we show that anminimal length might be related to the cosmological constant which, if thisnscenario is realized, is time dependent.n

authors: J. H. van Hateren
title: Fast recursive filters for simulating nonlinear dynamic systems
abstract: A fast and accurate computational scheme for simulating nonlinear dynamicnsystems is presented.
The scheme assumes that the system can be represented byna combination of components of only two different types: first-order low-passnfilters and static nonlinearities.
The parameters of these filters andnnonlinearities may depend on system variables, and the topology of the systemnmay be complex, including feedback.
Several examples taken from neurosciencenare given: phototransduction, photopigment bleaching, and spike generationnaccording to the Hodgkin-Huxley equations.
The scheme uses two slightlyndifferent forms of autoregressive filters, with an implicit delay of zero fornfeedforward control and an implicit delay of half a sample distance fornfeedback control.
On a fairly complex model of the macaque retinal horizontalncell it computes, for a given level of accuracy, 1-2 orders of magnitude fasternthan 4th-order Runge-Kutta.
The computational scheme has minimal memorynrequirements, and is also suited for computation on a stream processor, such asna GPU (Graphical Processing Unit).n

authors: M. Boucetta
title: Spectra and symmetric eigentensors of the Lichnerowicz Laplacian onn  $S^n$
abstract: We compute the eigenvalues with multiplicities of the Lichnerowicz Laplaciannacting on the space of symmetric covariant tensor fields on the Euclidiannsphere $S^n$.
The spaces of symmetric eigentensors are explicitly given.n

authors: G. Maciejewski, A. Niedzielski
title: CCD BV survey of 42 open clusters
abstract: We present results of a photometric survey whose aim was to derive structuralnand astrophysical parameters for 42 open clusters.

While our sample isndefinitively not representative of the total open cluster sample in the Galaxy,nit does cover a wide range of cluster parameters and is uniform enough to allownfor simple statistical considerations.
BV wide-field CCD photometry wasnobtained for open clusters for which photometric, structural, and dynamicalnevolution parameters were determined.
The limiting and core radii werendetermined by analyzing radial density profiles.
The ages, reddenings, andndistances were obtained from the solar metallicity isochrone fitting.
The massnfunction was used to study the dynamical state of the systems, mass segregationneffect and to estimate the total mass and number of cluster members.
This studynreports on the first determination of basic parameters for 11 out of 42nobserved open clusters.

The angular sizes for the majority of the observednclusters appear to be several times larger than the catalogue data indicate.nThe core and limiting cluster radii are correlated and the latter parameter isn3.2 times larger on average.
The limiting radius increases with the clustersnmass, and both the limiting and core radii decrease in the course of dynamicalnevolution.
For dynamically not advanced clusters, the mass function slope isnsimilar to the universal IMF slope.
For more evolved systems, the effect ofnevaporation of low-mass members is clearly visible.

The initial massnsegregation is present in all the observed young clusters, whereas thendynamical mass segregation appears in clusters older than about log(age)=8.nLow-mass stars are deficient in the cores of clusters older than log(age)=8.5nand not younger than one relaxation time.n

authors: Nikola Buric
title: Geometry and Dynamics of Quantum State Diffusion
abstract: Riemannian metric on real 2n-dimensional space associated with the equationngoverning complex diffusion of pure states of an open quantum system isnintroduced and studied.

Examples of a qubit under the influence of dephasingnand thermal environments are used to show that the curvature of the diffusionnmetric is a good indicator of the properties of the environment dominatednevolution and its stability.n

authors: Flaminio Flamini, Andreas Leopold Knutsen, Gianluca Pacienza, Edoardon  Sernesi
title: On families of rational curves in the Hilbert square of a surface (withn  an Appendix by Edoardo Sernesi)
abstract: Under natural hypotheses we give an upper bound on the dimension of familiesnof singular curves with hyperelliptic normalizations on a surface S with p_g(S)n>0 via the study of the associated families of rational curves in Hilb^2(S).n  We use this result to prove the existence of nodal curves of geometric genusn3 with hyperelliptic normalizations, on a general K3 surface, thus obtainingnspecific 2-dimensional families of rational curves in its Hilbert square.

Wendescribe two infinite series of examples of general, primitively polarized K3snsuch that their Hilbert squares contain a IP^2 or a threefold birational to anIP^1-bundle over a K3.n  We discuss some consequences on the Mori cone of the Hilbert square of angeneral K3.n

authors: Chang Chi Kwong and Ye Yeo
title: Anisotropy and Magnetic Field Effects on the Genuine Multipartiten  Entanglement of Multi-Qubit Heisenberg {it XY} Chains
abstract: It has been shown that, for the two-qubit Heisenberg XY model, anisotropy andnmagnetic field may together be used to produce entanglement for any finitentemperature by adjusting the external magnetic field beyond some finitencritical strength.
This interesting result arises from an analysis employingnthe Wootters concurrence, a computable measure of entanglement for two-qubitnstates.
Recently, Mintert {em et al.}
proposed generalizations of Woottersnconcurrence for multipartite states.
These MKB concurrences possess anmathematical property that enables one to understand the origin of thisncharacteristic behavior.
Here, we first study the effect of anisotropy andnmagnetic field on the multipartite thermal entanglement of a four-qubitnHeisenberg XY chain using the MKB concurrences.
We show that this modelnexhibits characteristic behavior similar to that of the two-qubit model.
Innaddition, we show that this can again be understood using the same mathematicalnproperty.
Next, we show that the six-qubit Heisenberg XY chain possessesnproperties necessary for it to have the characteristic behavior too.
Mostnimportantly, it is possible to directly measure the multipartite MKBnconcurrences of pure states.

This may provide an experimental verification ofnour conjecture that for a Heisenberg XY chain of any even number of qubits, itnis always possible to obtain non-zero genuine multipartite entanglement at anynfinite temperature by applying a sufficiently large magnetic field.n

authors: K. Aoki (for the PHENIX Collaboration)
title: Double Helicity Asymmetry of Inclusive pi0 Production in Polarized ppn  Collisions at sqrt(s)=62.4GeV
abstract: The proton spin structure is not understood yet and there has remained largenuncertainty on Delta g, the gluon spin contribution to the proton.

Doublenhelicity asymmetry (A_LL) of pi0 production in polarized pp collisions is usednto constrain Delta g. In this report, preliminary results of A_LL of pi0 in ppncollisions at sqrt(s) = 62.4 GeV measured by PHENIX experiment in 2006 isnpresented.
It can probe higer x region than the previously reported pi0 A_LL atnsqrt(s) = 200 GeV thanks to the lower center of mass energy.n

authors: O. Ozcan, E. Akturk and R. Sever
title: Time dependence of joint entropy of oscillating quantum systems
abstract: The time dependent entropy (or Leipniks entropy) of harmonic and dampednharmonic oscillators is extensively investigated by using time dependent wavenfunction obtained by the Feynman path integral method.
Our results for simplenharmonic oscillator are in agrement with the literature.
However, the jointnentropy of damped harmonic oscillator shows remarkable discontinuity with timenfor certain values of damping factor.
According to the results, the envelop ofnthe joint entropy curve increases with time monotonically.
This results is thengeneral properties of the envelop of the joint entropy curve for quantumnsystems.n

authors: Jerome Lodewyck and Philippe Grangier
title: Tight bound on coherent states quantum key distribution with heterodynen  detection
abstract: We propose a new upper bound for the eavesdroppers information in the directnand reverse reconciliated coherent states quantum key distribution protocolsnwith heterodyne detection.
This bound is derived by maximizing the leakedninformation over the symplectic group of transformations that spans everynphysical Gaussian attack on individual pulses.
We exhibit four differentnattacks that reach this bound, which shows that this bound is tight.
Finally,nwe compare the secret key rate obtained with this new bound to the homodynenrate.n

authors: Seick Kim
title: Gaussian estimates for fundamental solutions of second order parabolicn  systems with time-independent coefficients
abstract: Auscher, McIntosh and Tchamitchian studied the heat kernels of second ordernelliptic operators in divergence form with complex bounded measurablencoefficients on $mathbb{R}^n$.
In particular, in the case when $n=2$ theynobtained Gaussian upper bound estimates for the heat kernel without imposingnfurther assumption on the coefficients.

We study the fundamental solutions ofnthe systems of second order parabolic equations in the divergence form withnbounded, measurable, time-independent coefficients, and extend their results tonthe systems of parabolic equations.n

authors: Burgy Laurent (INRIA Futurs), Laurent Reveill`ere (INRIA Futurs),n  Julia Lawall (DIKU), Gilles Muller (INRIA Rennes)
title: A Language-Based Approach for Improving the Robustness of Networkn  Application Protocol Implementations
abstract: The secure and robust functioning of a network relies on the defect-freenimplementation of network applications.
As network protocols have becomenincreasingly complex, however, hand-writing network message processing code hasnbecome increasingly error-prone.
In this paper, we present a domain-specificnlanguage, Zebu, for describing protocol message formats and related processingnconstraints.
From a Zebu specification, a compiler automatically generatesnstubs to be used by an application to parse network messages.
Zebu is easy tonuse, as it builds on notations used in RFCs to describe protocol grammars.
Zebunis also efficient, as the memory usage is tailored to application needs andnmessage fragments can be specified to be processed on demand.
Finally,nZebu-based applications are robust, as the Zebu compiler automatically checksnspecification consistency and generates parsing stubs that include validationnof the message structure.
Using a mutation analysis in the context of SIP andnRTSP, we show that Zebu significantly improves application robustness.n

authors: R. Davies, F. Mueller Sanchez, R. Genzel, L. Tacconi, E. Hicks, S.n  Friedrich, A. Sternberg
title: A Close Look at Star Formation around Active Galactic Nuclei
abstract: We analyse star formation in the nuclei of 9 Seyfert galaxies at spatialnresolutions down to 0.085arcsec, corresponding to length scales of less thann10pc in some objects.
Our data were taken mostly with the near infrarednadaptive optics integral field spectrograph SINFONI.
The stellar light profilesntypically have size scales of a few tens of parsecs.
In two cases there isnunambiguous kinematic evidence for stellar disks on these scales.
In thennuclear regions there appear to have been recent - but no longer active -nstarbursts in the last 10-300Myr.
The stellar luminosity is less than a fewnpercent of the AGN in the central 10pc, whereas on kiloparsec scales thenluminosities are comparable.

The surface stellar luminosity density follows ansimilar trend in all the objects, increasing steadily at smaller radii up ton10^{13}L_sun/kpc^2 in the central few parsecs, where the mass surface densitynexceeds 10^4M_sun/pc^2.
The intense starbursts were probably Eddington limitednand hence inevitably short-lived, implying that the starbursts occur innmultiple short bursts.
The data hint at a delay of 50--100Myr between the onsetnof star formation and subsequent fuelling of the black hole.
We discuss whethernthis may be a consequence of the role that stellar ejecta could play innfuelling the black hole.

While a significant mass is ejected by OB winds andnsupernovae, their high velocity means that very little of it can be accreted.nOn the other hand winds from AGB stars ultimately dominate the total mass loss,nand they can also be accreted very efficiently because of their slow speeds.n

authors: Fernando Muro, Stefan Schwede, Neil Strickland
title: Triangulated categories without models
abstract: We exhibit examples of triangulated categories which are neither the stablencategory of a Frobenius category nor a full triangulated subcategory of thenhomotopy category of a stable model category.
Even more drastically, ournexamples do not admit any non-trivial exact functors to or from these algebraicnrespectively topological triangulated categories.n

authors: Wei Lao, Michael Mayer
title: U-max-Statistics
abstract: In 1948, W. Hoeffding introduced a large class of unbiased estimators callednU-statistics, defined as the average value of a real-valued k-variate functionnh calculated at all possible sets of k points from a random sample.
In thenpresent paper we investigate the corresponding extreme value analogue, which wenshall call U-max-statistics.
We are concerned with the behavior of the largestnvalue of such function h instead of its average.
Examples of U-max-statisticsnare the diameter or the largest scalar product within a random sample.nU-max-statistics of higher degrees are given by triameters and other metricninvariants.n

authors: Yuhei Miyauchi, Riichiro Saito, Kentaro Sato, Yutaka Ohno, Shinyan  Iwasaki, Takashi Mizutani, Jie Jiang, Shigeo Maruyama
title: Dependence of exciton transition energy of single-walled carbonn  nanotubes on surrounding dielectric materials
abstract: We theoretically investigate the dependence of exciton transition energies onndielectric constant of surrounding materials.

We make a simple model for thenrelation between dielectric constant of environment and a static dielectricnconstant describing the effects of electrons in core states, $sigma$ bonds andnsurrounding materials.
Although the model is very simple, calculated resultsnwell reproduce experimental transition energy dependence on dielectric constantnof various surrounding materials.n

authors: S. Esposito, R. De Risi, L. Somma
title: Mpemba effect and phase transitions in the adiabatic cooling of watern  before freezing
abstract: An accurate experimental investigation on the Mpemba effect (that is, thenfreezing of initially hot water before cold one) is carried out, showing thatnin the adiabatic cooling of water a relevant role is played by supercooling asnwell as by phase transitions taking place at 6 +/- 1 oC, 3.5 +/- 0.5 oC and 1.3n+/- 0.6 oC, respectively.
The last transition, occurring with a non negligiblenprobability of 0.21, has not been detected earlier.

Supported by thenexperimental results achieved, a thorough theoretical analysis of supercoolingnand such phase transitions, which are interpreted in terms of differentnordering of clusters of molecules in water, is given.n

authors: Laura Rebuzzini, Roberto Artuso, Shmuel Fishman and Italo Guarneri
title: Effects of atomic interactions on Quantum Accelerator Modes
abstract: We consider the influence of the inclusion of interatomic interactions on thendelta-kicked accelerator model.

Our analysis concerns in particular quantumnaccelerator modes, namely quantum ballistic transport near quantal resonances.nThe atomic interaction is modelled by a Gross-Pitaevskii cubic nonlinearity,nand we address both attractive (focusing) and repulsive (defocusing) cases.
Thenmost remarkable effect is enhancement or damping of the accelerator modes,ndepending on the sign of the nonlinear parameter.
We provide arguments showingnthat the effect persists beyond mean-field description, and lies within thenexperimentally accessible parameter range.n

authors: Mariusz P. Dabrowski, Tomasz Denkiewicz and Martin A. Hendry
title: How far is it to a sudden future singularity of pressure?
abstract: We discuss the constraints coming from current observations of type Iansupernovae on cosmological models which allow sudden future singularities ofnpressure (with the scale factor and the energy density regular).
We show thatnsuch a sudden singularity may happen in the very near future (e.g.

within tennmillion years) and its prediction at the present moment of cosmic evolutionncannot be distinguished, with current observational data, from the predictionngiven by the standard quintessence scenario of future evolution.

Fortunately,nsudden future singularities are characterized by a momentary peak of infinitentidal forces only; there is no geodesic incompletness which means that thenevolution of the universe may eventually be continued throughout until anothern``more serious singularity such as Big-Crunch or Big-Rip.n

authors: Yuval Weiss, Moshe Goldstein and Richard Berkovits
title: Disorder effect on the Friedel oscillations in a one-dimensional Mottn  insulator
abstract: The Friedel oscillations resulting from coupling a quantum dot to one edge ofna disordered one-dimensional wire in the Mott insulator regime, are calculatednnumerically using the DMRG method.
By investigating the influence of thendisorder on the Friedel oscillations decay we find that the effect of disordernis reduced by increasing the interaction strength.
This behavior is opposite tonthe recently reported influence of disorder in the Anderson insulator regime,nwhere disorder led to a stronger decay of the Friedel oscillations.n

authors: P. A. Evans (Keele University and University of Leicester) and Coeln  Hellier (Keele University)
title: Why do some intermediate polars show soft X-ray emission? A survey ofn  XMM-Newton spectra
abstract: We make a systematic analysis of the XMM-Newton X-ray spectra of intermediatenpolars (IPs) and find that, contrary to the traditional picture, most show ansoft blackbody component.
We compare the results with those from AM Her starsnand deduce that the blackbody emission arises from reprocessing of hard X-rays,nrather than from the blobby accretion sometimes seen in AM Hers.

Whether an IPnshows a blackbody component appears to depend primarily on geometric factors: anblackbody is not seen in those that have accretion footprints that are alwaysnobscured by accretion curtains or are only visible when foreshortened on thenwhite-dwarf limb.

Thus we argue against previous suggestions that the blackbodynemission characterises a separate sub-group of IPs which are more akin to AMnHers, and develop a unified picture of the blackbody emission in these stars.n

authors: Michele Fabrizio (SISSA and ICTP, Trieste, Italy)
title: Gutzwiller description of non-magnetic Mott insulators: a dimer latticen  model
abstract: We introduce a novel extension of the Gutzwiller variational wavefunctionnable to deal with insulators that escape any mean-field like description, asnfor instance non-magnetic insulators.
As an application, we study the Mottntransition from a paramagnetic metal into a non-magnetic Peierls, ornvalence-bond, Mott insulator.

We analyze this model by means of our Gutzwillernwavefunction analytically in the limit of large coordination lattices, where wenfind that: (1) the Mott transition is first order; (2) the Peierls gap is largenin the Mott insulator, although it is mainly contributed by the electronnrepulsion; (3) singlet-superconductivity arises around the transition.n

authors: Azam Gholami, Martin Falcke, Erwin Frey
title: Velocity oscillations in actin-based motility
abstract: We present a simple and generic theoretical description of actin-basednmotility, where polymerization of filaments maintains propulsion.
The dynamicsnis driven by polymerization kinetics at the filaments free ends, crosslinkingnof the actin network, attachment and detachment of filaments to the obstacleninterfaces and entropic forces.
We show that spontaneous oscillations in thenvelocity emerge in a broad range of parameter values, and compare our findingsnwith experiments.n

authors: D.S. Dean and R.R. Horgan
title: Path integrals for stiff polymers applied to membrane physics
abstract: Path integrals similar to those describing stiff polymers arise in thenHelfrich model for membranes.
We show how these types of path integrals can benevaluated and apply our results to study the thermodynamics of a minoritynstripe phase in a bulk membrane.

The fluctuation induced contribution to thenline tension between the stripe and the bulk phase is computed, as well as theneffective interaction between the two phases in the tensionless case where thentwo phases have differing bending rigidities.n

authors: J.F. Libby (on behalf of the LHCb Collaboration)
title: Measuring CP violation in Bs->phi phi with LHCb
abstract: Sensitivity studies to the CP-violating parameters of the decay Bs->phi phinwith the LHCb experiment are presented.
The decay proceeds via a b->s s anti-sngluonic-penguin quark transition, which is sensitive to contributions fromnbeyond the Standard Model particles.

A time-dependent angular analysis ofnsimulated data leads to an expected statistical uncertainty of 6 degrees on anynnew physics induced CP-violating phase for a sample corresponding to 2 fb^{-1}nof integrated luminosity.
The expected precision on sin2beta from the relatedndecay Bd->phi K0S is also discussed.n

authors: B. Lanzoni (1,2), N. Sanna (3), F.R. Ferraro (1), E. Valenti (4), G.n  Beccari (2,5,6), R.P. Schiavon (7), R.T. Rood (7), M. Mapelli (8), S.n  Sigurdsson (9) - (1 Dip. Astro., Bologna; 2 INAF--Oss. Astro., Bologna; 3n  Dip. Fisica, Roma Tor Vergata; 4 ESO-Chile; 5 Dip. Scienze dellan  Comunicazione, Teramo; 6 INAF--Oss. Astro. Collurania, Teramo; 7 Astronomyn  Dep., University of Virginia; 8 Univ. of Zurich, Institute for Theoreticaln  Physics; 9 Dep. of Astronomy and Astrophysics, The Pennsylvania Staten  University)
title: A Panchromatic Study of the Globular Cluster NGC 1904. I: The Bluen  Straggler Population
abstract: By combining high-resolution (HST-WFPC2) and wide-field ground based (2.2mnESO-WFI) and space (GALEX) observations, we have collected a multi-wavelengthnphotometric data base (ranging from the far UV to the near infrared) of thengalactic globular cluster NGC1904 (M79).
The sample covers the entire clusternextension, from the very central regions up to the tidal radius.
In the presentnpaper such a data set is used to study the BSS population and its radialndistribution.

A total number of 39 bright ($m_{218}le 19.5$) BSS has beenndetected, and they have been found to be highly segregated in the cluster core.nNo significant upturn in the BSS frequency has been observed in the outskirtsnof NGC 1904, in contrast to other clusters (M 3, 47 Tuc, NGC 6752, M 5) studiednwith the same technique.

Such evidences, coupled with the large radius ofnavoidance estimated for NGC 1904 ($r_{avoid}sim 30$ core radii), indicate thatnthe vast majority of the cluster heavy stars (binaries) has already sunk to thencore.

Accordingly, extensive dynamical simulations suggest that BSS formed bynmass transfer activity in primordial binaries evolving in isolation in thencluster outskirts represent only a negligible (0--10%) fraction of the overallnpopulation.n

authors: W. Emam and S. Khalil
title: Higgs and Z Phenomenology in B-L extension of the Standard Model at LHC
abstract: The phenomenology of the low scale U(1)_{B-L} extension of the standard modelnand its implications at LHC is presented.
In this model, an extra gauge bosonncorresponding to B-L gauge symmetry and an extra SM singlet scalar (heavynHiggs) are predicted.
We show a detailed analysis of both heavy and lightnHiggses decay and production in addition to the possible decay channels of thennew gauge boson.
We find that the cross sections of the SM-like Higgsnproduction are reduced by ~ 20%-30%, while its decay branching ratios remainnintact.

The extra Higgs has relatively small cross sections and the branchingnratios of Z-> l^+ l^- are of order ~20% compared to ~ 3% of the SM resuls.nHence, the search for Z is accessible via a clean dilepton signal at LHC.n

authors: Eric Bonnet (IPNO, GANIL), Francesca Gulminelli (LPCC), Bernardn  Borderie (IPNO), Nicolas Le Neindre (IPNO), Marie-France Rivet (IPNO)
title: What Can be Learned Studying the Distribution of the Biggest Fragment ?
abstract: In the canonical formalism of statistical physics, a signature of a firstnorder phase transition for finite systems is the bimodal distribution of annorder parameter.
Previous thermodynamical studies of nuclear sources producednin heavy-ion collisions provide information which support the existence of anphase transition in those finite nuclear systems.
Some results suggest that thenobservable Z1 (charge of the biggest fragment) can be considered as a reliablenorder parameter of the transition.
This talk will show how from peripheralncollisions studied with the INDRA detector at GSI we can obtain this bimodalnbehaviour of Z1.

Getting rid of the entrance channel effects and under thenconstraint of an equiprobable distribution of excitation energy (E*), we usenthe canonical description of a phase transition to link this bimodal behaviournwith the residual convexity of the entropy.
Theoretical (with and without phasentransition) and experimental Z1-E* correlations are compared.
This comparisonnallows us to rule out the case without transition.

Moreover that quantitativencomparison provides us with information about the coexistence region in thenZ1-E* plane which is in good agreement with that obtained with the signal ofnabnormal uctuations of configurational energy (microcanonical negative heatncapacity).n

authors: Mehmet Cenkci
title: The p-adic generalized twisted (h,q)-euler-l-function and itsn  applications
abstract: The purpose of this paper is to construct the p-adic twistedn(h,q)-Euler-l-function, which interpolates the twisted generalized twistednEuler numbers attached to chi at a negative integer.n

authors: Istvan Ballai
title: Global coronal seismology
abstract: Following the observation and analysis of large-scale coronal wave-likendisturbances, we discuss the theoretical progress made in the field of globalncoronal seismology.
Using simple mathematical techniques we determine averagenvalues for magnetic field together with a magnetic map of the quiet Sun.
Theninteraction between global coronal waves and coronal loops allows us to studynloop oscillations in a much wider context, i.e.
we connect global and localncoronal oscillations.n

authors: Ludovic Dan Lemle (FIH)
title: La formule de Lie-Trotter pour les semi-groupes fortement continus
abstract: In this research project we presents the general properties, the spectralnproperties and the representation formulas for $C_0$-semigroups of linearnoperators in Banach spacesn

authors: Bomee Lee, Jounghun Lee (Seoul National Univ.)
title: Reconstructing the Intrinsic Triaxial Shape of the Virgo Cluster
abstract: To use galaxy clusters as a cosmological probe, it is important to accountnfor their triaxiality.

Assuming that the triaxial shapes of galaxy clusters areninduced by the tidal interaction with the surrounding matter, Lee and Kangnrecently developed a reconstruction algorithm for the measurement of the axialnratio of a triaxial cluster.
We examine the validity of this reconstructionnalgorithm by performing an observational test of it with the Virgo cluster as antarget.
We first modify the LK06 algorithm by incorporating the two dimensionalnprojection effect.

Then, we analyze the 1275 member galaxies from the VirgonCluster Catalogue and find the projected direction of the Virgo cluster majornaxis by measuring the anisotropy in the spatial distribution of the memberngalaxies in the two dimensional projected plane.
Applying the modifiednreconstruction algorithm to the analyzed data, we find that the axial ratio ofnthe triaxial Virgo cluster is (1: 0.54 : 0.73).
This result is consistent withnthe recent observational report from the Virgo Cluster Survey, proving thenrobustness of the reconstruction algorithm.
It is also found that at the innernradii the shape tends to be more like prolate.
We discuss the possible effectnof the Virgo cluster triaxiality on the mass estimation.n

authors: James T. Ferguson
title: Flat Pencils of Symplectic Connections and Hamiltonian Operators ofn  Degree 2
abstract: Bi-Hamiltonian structures involving Hamiltonian operators of degree 2 arenstudied.
Firstly, pairs of degree 2 operators are considered in terms of annalgebra structure on the space of 1-forms, related to so-called FermionicnNovikov algebras.
Then, degree 2 operators are considered as deformations ofnhydrodynamic type Poisson brackets.n

authors: I. S. Smirnova, A. V. Bazhenov, T. N. Fursova, A. V. Dubovitskii, L.n  S. Uspenskaya, M. Yu. Maksimuk
title: IR-active optical phonons in Pnma-1, Pnma-2 and R3c phases ofn  LaMnO_{3+delta}
abstract: Infrared-active phonons in LaMnO_{3+delta} were studied by means of thenreflection and transmission spectroscopy from 50 to 800 cm^{-1} at roomntemperature.
Powder and ceramic samples of the phases of Pnma-2 (delta=0.02),nPnma-1 (delta=0.08), and R3c (delta=0.15) were investigated.
Besides,nenergies of the dipole-active phonons in Pnma-2, Pnma-1 phases were obtained bynlattice-dynamics calculations.
The transformations of IR-active phonons withnthe increase of delta in the sequence of Pnma-2, Pnma-1, R3c are discussed.n

authors: Alberto S. Cattaneo, Florian Schaetz
title: Equivalences of Higher Derived Brackets
abstract: This note elaborates on Th.
Voronovs constructionn[math/0304038,math/0412202] of $L_infty$-structures via higher derivednbrackets with a Maurer-Cartan element.
It is shown that gauge equivalentnMaurer-Cartan elements induce $L_infty$-isomorphic structures.
Applications innsymplectic, Poisson and Dirac geometry are discussed.n

authors: Oscar J. C. Dias and Pedro J. Silva
title: Euclidean analysis of the entropy functional formalism
abstract: The attractor mechanism implies that the supersymmetric black hole nearnhorizon solution is defined only in terms of the conserved charges and isntherefore independent of asymptotic moduli.

Starting only with the near horizonngeometry, Sens entropy functional formalism computes the entropy of an extremenblack hole by means of a Legendre transformation where the electric fields arendefined as conjugated variables to the electric charges.
However, traditionalnEuclidean methods require the knowledge of the full geometry to compute thenblack hole thermodynamic quantities.
We establish the connection between thenentropy functional formalism and the standard Euclidean formalism taken at zerontemperature.
We find that Sens entropy function f (on-shell) matches thenzero temperature limit of the Euclidean action.
Moreover, Sens near horizonnangular and electric fields agree with the chemical potentials that are definednfrom the zero-temperature limit of the Euclidean formalism.n

authors: Arzhang Angoshtari, Mir Abbas Jalali
title: On the existence of chaotic circumferential waves in spinning disks
abstract: We use a third-order perturbation theory and Melnikovs method to prove thenexistence of chaos in spinning circular disks subject to a lateral point load.nWe show that the emergence of transverse homoclinic and heteroclinic pointsnrespectively lead to a random reversal in the traveling direction ofncircumferential waves and a random phase shift of magnitude $pi$ for bothnforward and backward wave components.
These long-term phenomena occur innimperfect low-speed disks sufficiently far from fundamental resonances.n

authors: Jan Rusz, Stefano Rubino, Peter Schattschneider
title: First principles theory of chiral dichroism in electron microscopyn  applied to 3d ferromagnets
abstract: Recently it was demonstrated (Schattschneider et al., Nature 441 (2006),n486), that an analogue of the X-ray magnetic circular dichroism (XMCD)nexperiment can be performed with the transmission electron microscope (TEM).nThe new phenomenon has been named energy-loss magnetic chiral dichroism (EMCD).nIn this work we present a detailed ab initio study of the chiral dichroism innthe Fe, Co and Ni transition elements.
We discuss the methods used for thensimulations together with the validity and accuracy of the treatment, whichncan, in principle, apply to any given crystalline specimen.
The dependence ofnthe dichroic signal on the sample thickness, accuracy of the detector positionnand the size of convergence and collection angles is calculated.n

authors: S. Calchi Novati (1,2), G. Covone (3), F. De Paolis (4), M. Dominikn  (5), Y. Giraud-Heraud (6), G. Ingrosso (4), Ph. Jetzer (7), L. Mancini (1,2),n  A. Nucita (4), G. Scarpetta (1,2) F. Strafella (4) and A. Gould (8) (The PLANn  collaboration) ((1) University of Salerno, (2) INFN, Napoli, (3) INAF - OAC,n  (4) University of Lecce, (5) SUPA, (6) APC, (7) University of Zurich, (8)n  OSU)
title: Probing MACHOs by observation of M31 pixel lensing with the 1.5m Loianon  telescope
abstract: We analyse a series of pilot observations in order to study microlensing ofn(unresolved) stars in M31 with the 1.5m Loiano telescope, includingnobservations on both identified variable source stars and reported microlensingnevents.
We also look for previously unknown variability and discover a nova.
Wendiscuss an observing strategy for an extended campaign with the goal ofndetermining whether MACHOs exist or whether all microlensing events arencompatible with lens stars in M31.n

authors: Yao HengShuai
title: Preconditioned Temporal Difference Learning

authors: W. Cassing (Univ. of Giessen)
title: QCD thermodynamics and confinement from a dynamical quasiparticle pointn  of view
abstract: In this study it is demonstrated that a simple picture of then  QCD gluon liquid emerges in the dynamical quasiparticle model that specifiesnthe active degrees of freedom in the time-like sector and yields a potentialnenergy density in the space-like sector.

By using the time-like gluon densityn(or scalar gluon density) as an independent degree of freedom - instead of thentemperature $T$ as a Lagrange parameter - variations of the potential energyndensity lead to effective mean-fields for time-like gluons and an effectivengluon-gluon interaction strength at low density.

The latter yields a simplendynamical picture for the gluon fusion to color neutral glueballs whennapproaching the phase boundary from a temperature higher than $T_c$ and pavesnthe way for an off-shell transport theoretical description of the partonndynamics.n

authors: Lorenzo Cappellari
title: Trellis-Coded Quantization Based on Maximum-Hamming-Distance Binaryn  Codes
abstract: Most design approaches for trellis-coded quantization take advantage of thenduality of trellis-coded quantization with trellis-coded modulation, and usenthe same empirically-found convolutional codes to label the trellis branches.nThis letter presents an alternative approach that instead takes advantage ofnmaximum-Hamming-distance convolutional codes.
The proposed source codes arenshown to be competitive with the best in the literature for the samencomputational complexity.n

authors: A. M. Rey, V. Gritsev, I. Bloch, E. Demler and M.D. Lukin
title: Preparation and detection of magnetic quantum phases in opticaln  superlattices
abstract: We describe a novel approach to prepare, detect and characterize magneticnquantum phases in ultra-cold spinor atoms loaded in optical superlattices.
Ourntechnique makes use of singlet-triplet spin manipulations in an array ofnisolated double well potentials in analogy to recently demonstrated quantumncontrol in semiconductor quantum dots.
We also discuss the many-bodynsinglet-triplet spin dynamics arising from coherent coupling between nearestnneighbor double wells and derive an effective description for such system.
Wenuse it to study the generation of complex magnetic states by adiabatic andnnon-equilibrium dynamics.n

authors: A.Matoussi, M. Xu
title: Sobolev solution for semilinear PDE with obstacle under monotonicityn  condition
abstract: We prove the existence and uniqueness of the solution of a semilinear PDEsnand also PDEs with obstacle under monotonicity condition.
Moreover we give thenprobabilistic interpretation of the Sobolevs solutions in term of Backward SDEnand reflected Backward SDE respectively.n

authors: Thomas Royen
title: Exact distribution of the sample variance from a gamma parentn  distribution
abstract: Several representations of the exact cdf of the sum of squares of nnindependent gamma-distributed random variables Xi are given, in particular by anseries of gamma distribution functions.

Using a characterization of the gammandistribution by Laha, an expansion of the exact distribution of the samplenvariance is derived by a Taylor series approach with the former distribution asnits leading term.
In particular for integer orders alpha some further seriesnare provided, including a convex combination of gamma distributions for alpha =n1 and nearly of this type for alpha > 1.
Furthermore, some representations ofnthe distribution of the angle Phi between (X1,...,Xn) and (1,...,1) are givennby orthogonal series.
All these series are based on the same sequence of easilyncomputed moments of cos(Phi).n

authors: A. Kurkela
title: Framework for non-perturbative analysis of a Z(3)-symmetric effectiven  theory of finite temperature QCD
abstract: We study a three dimensional Z(3)-symmetric effective theory of highntemperature QCD.
The exact lattice-continuum relations, needed in order tonperform lattice simulations with physical parameters, are computed to ordernO(a^0) in lattice perturbation theory.
Lattice simulations are performed tondetermine the phase structure of a subset of the parameter space.n

authors: Jorge Mondejar and Antonio Pineda
title: Constraints on Regge models from perturbation theory
abstract: We study the constraints that the operator product expansion imposes on largen$N_c$ inspired QCD models for current-current correlators.
We focus on thenconstraints obtained by going beyond the leading-order parton computation.

Wenexplicitly show that, assumed a given mass spectrum: linear Regge behavior inn$n$ (the principal quantum number) plus corrections in $1/n$, we can obtain thenlogarithmic (and constant) behavior in $n$ of the decay constants within ansystematic expansion in $1/n$.
Our example shows that it is possible to havendifferent large $n$ behavior for the vector and pseudo-vector mass spectrum andnyet comply with all the constraints from the operator product expansion.n

authors: Roland Rabanal
title: Asymptotic stability at infinity for bidimensional Hurwitz vector fields
abstract: Let $X:U-->R^2$ be a differentiable vector field.
Set $Spc(X)={eigenvalues ofnDX(z) : zin U}$.
This $X$ is called Hurwitz if $Spc(X)subset{zinnC:Re(z)<0}$.
Suppose that $X$ is Hurwitz and $Usubset R^2$ is the complementnof a compact set.
Then by adding to $X$ a constant $v$ one obtains that theninfinity is either an attractor or a repellor for $X+v.$n

authors: C. Eames, M. I. J. Probert, S. P. Tear
title: Quantitative LEED I-V and ab initio study of the Si(111)-3x2-Sm surfacen  structure and the missing half order spots in the 3x1 diffraction pattern
abstract: We have used Low Energy Electron Diffraction (LEED) I-V analysis and abninitio calculations to quantitatively determine the honeycomb chain modelnstructure for the Si(111)-3x2-Sm surface.
This structure and a similar 3x1nrecontruction have been observed for many Alkali-Earth and Rare-Earth metals onnthe Si(111) surface.

Our ab initio calculations show that there are two almostndegenerate sites for the Sm atom in the unit cell and the LEED I-V analysisnreveals that an admixture of the two in a ratio that slightly favours the sitenwith the lower energy is the best match to experiment.

We show that the I-Vncurves are insensitive to the presence of the Sm atom and that this results inna very low intensity for the half order spots which might explain thenappearance of a 3x1 LEED pattern produced by all of the structures with a 3x2nunit cell.n

authors: A. Andrasi and J. C. Taylor
title: Renormalization of Hamiltonian QCD
abstract: We study to one-loop order the renormalization of QCD in the Coulomb gaugenusing the Hamitonian formalism.
Divergences occur which might requirencounter-terms outside the Hamiltonian formalism, but they can be cancelled by anredefinition of the Yang-Mills electric field.n

authors: P. Jakobsson, J. P. U. Fynbo
title: What made GRBs 060505 and 060614?
abstract: Recent observations of two nearby SN-less long-duration gamma-ray burstsn(GRBs), which share no obvious characteristics in their prompt emission,nsuggest a new phenomenological type of massive stellar death.
Here we brieflynreview the observational properties of these bursts and their proposed hosts,nand discuss whether a new GRB classification scheme is needed.n

authors: F. Wilken, D. Bauer
title: Momentum distributions in time-dependent density functional theory:n  Product phase approximation for non-sequential double ionization in strongn  laser fields
abstract: We investigate the possibility to deduce momentum space properties fromntime-dependent density functional calculations.
Electron and ion momentumndistributions after double ionization of a model Helium atom in a strongnfew-cycle laser pulse are studied.

We show that, in this case, the choice ofnsuitable functionals for the observables is considerably more important thannthe choice of the correlation potential in the time-dependent Kohn-Shamnequations.
By comparison with the solution of the time-dependent Schroedingernequation, the insufficiency of functionals neglecting electron correlation isndemonstrated.

We construct a functional of the Kohn-Sham orbitals, which innprinciple yields the exact momentum distributions of the electrons and the ion.nThe product-phase approximation is introduced, which reduces the problem ofnapproximating this functional significantly.n

authors: Catalina Curceanu (on behalf of the AMADEUS Collaboration)
title: The Amadeus project at Dafne
abstract: The change of the hadron masses and hadron interactions in the nuclear mediumnand the structure of cold dense hadronic matter are hot topics of hadronnphysics today.

These important, yet unsolved, problems will be the researchnfield of AMADEUS (Antikaonic Matter At DAFNE: Experiments with UnravelingnSpectroscopy) - new experiment proposal at DAFNE accelerator at LNF-INFN.nAMADEUS will search for antikaon-mediated deeply bound nuclear states producednin helium by stopping K- from DAFNE, both in the formation and in the decaynprocesses.n

authors: P. Castorina, D. Kharzeev and H. Satz
title: Thermal Hadronization and Hawking-Unruh Radiation in QCD
abstract: We conjecture that because of color confinement, the physical vacuum forms annevent horizon for quarks and gluons which can be crossed only by quantumntunneling, i.e., through the QCD counterpart of Hawking radiation by blacknholes.

Since such radiation cannot transmit information to the outside, it mustnbe thermal, of a temperature determined by the chromodynamic force at thenconfinement surface, and it must maintain color neutrality.
We explore thenpossibility that the resulting process provides a common mechanism for thermalnhadron production in high energy interactions, from $e^+e^-$ annihilation tonheavy ion collisions.n

authors: A. Crepieux, M. Guigou, A. Popoff, P. Devillard, and T. Martin
title: Photo-assisted shot noise in Coulomb interacting systems
abstract: We consider the fluctuations of the electrical current (shot noise) in thenpresence of a voltage time-modulation.
For a non-interacting metal, it is knownnthat the derivative of the photo-assisted noise has a staircase behavior.

Innthe presence of Coulomb interactions, we show that the photo-assisted noisenpresents a more complex profile, in particular for the two following systems:n1) a two-dimensional electron gas in the fractional quantum Hall regime fornwhich we have obtained evenly spaced singularities in the noise derivative,nwith a spacing related to the filling factor and, 2) a carbon nanotube fornwhich a smoothed staircase in the noise derivative is obtained.n

authors: Y. Momany, E.V. Held, I. Saviane, S. Zaggia, L. Rizzi and M.n  Gullieuszik
title: The blue plume population in dwarf spheroidal galaxies: genuine bluen  stragglers or young stellar population?
abstract: Abridged... Blue stragglers (BSS) are thought to be the product of eithernprimordial or collisional binary systems.
In the context of dwarf spheroidalngalaxies it is hard to firmly disentangle a genuine BSS population from youngnmain sequence (MS) stars tracing a ~1-2 Gyr old star forming episode.

Assumingnthat their blue plume populations are made of BSS, we estimate the BSSnfrequency for 8 Local Group non star-forming dwarf galaxies, using ancompilation of ground and space based photometry.n  Our results can be summarized as follows: (i) The BSS frequency in dwarfngalaxies, at any given Mv, is always higher than that in globular clusters ofnsimilar luminosities; (ii) the BSS frequency for the lowest luminosity dwarfngalaxies is in excellent agreement with that observed in the Milky Way halo;nand most interestingly (iii) derive a statistically significantnanti-correlation between the BSS frequency and the galaxy Mv.n  The low density, almost collision-less, environments of our dwarf galaxynsample allow us to infer (i) their very low dynamical evolution; (ii) annegligible production of collisional BSS; and consequently (iii) that theirnblue plumes are mainly made of primordial binaries.
The dwarf galaxiesnanti-correlation can be used as a discriminator: galaxies obeying thenanti-correlation are more likely to possess genuine primordial BSS rather thannyoung main sequence stars.n

authors: Dongseok Kim, Hye Kyung Kim and Jaeun Lee
title: Generalized characteristic polynomials of graph bundles
abstract: In this paper, we find computational formulae for generalized characteristicnpolynomials of graph bundles.
We show that the number of spanning trees in angraph is the partial derivative (at (0,1)) of the generalized characteristicnpolynomial of the graph.

Since the reciprocal of the Bartholdi zeta function ofna graph can be derived from the generalized characteristic polynomial of angraph, consequently, the Bartholdi zeta function of a graph bundle can bencomputed by using our computational formulae.n

authors: Dongseok Kim and Jaeun Lee
title: Some invariants of pretzel links
abstract: We show that nontrivial classical pretzel knots L(p,q,r) are hyperbolic withneight exceptions which are torus knots.
We find Conway polynomials of n-pretzelnlinks using a new computation tree.

As applications, we compute the genera ofnn-pretzel links using these polynomials and find the basket number of pretzelnlinks by showing that the genus and the canonical genus of a pretzel link arenthe same.n

authors: Benjamin Jourdain (CERMICS), Mohamed Sbai (CERMICS)
title: Exact retrospective Monte Carlo computation of arithmetic average Asiann  options
abstract: Taking advantage of the recent litterature on exact simulation algorithmsn(Beskos, Papaspiliopoulos and Roberts) and unbiased estimation of thenexpectation of certain fonctional integrals (Wagner, Beskos et al.
andnFearnhead et al.

), we apply an exact simulation based technique for pricingncontinuous arithmetic average Asian options in the Black and Scholes framework.nUnlike existing Monte Carlo methods, we are no longer prone to thendiscretization bias resulting from the approximation of continuous timenprocesses through discrete sampling.
Numerical results of simulation studiesnare presented and variance reduction problems are considered.n

authors: Frank Lechermann, Antoine Georges, Gabriel Kotliar, Olivier Parcollet
title: Rotationally-invariant slave-boson formalism and momentum dependence ofn  the quasiparticle weight
abstract: We generalize the rotationally-invariant formulation of the slave-bosonnformalism to multiorbital models, with arbitrary interactions, crystal fields,nand multiplet structure.
This allows for the study of multiplet effects on thennature of low-energy quasiparticles.
Non-diagonal components of the matrix ofnquasiparticle weights can be calculated within this framework.

When combinednwith cluster extensions of dynamical mean-field theory, this method allows usnto address the effects of spatial correlations, such as the generation of thensuperexchange and the momentum dependence of the quasiparticle weight.

Wenillustrate the method on a two-band Hubbard model, a Hubbard model made of twoncoupled layers, and a two-dimensional single-band Hubbard model (within antwo-site cellular dynamical mean-field approximation).n

authors: Robert Seiringer
title: On the failure of subadditivity of the Wigner-Yanase entropy
abstract: It was recently shown by Hansen that the Wigner-Yanase entropy is, forngeneral states of quantum systems, not subadditive with respect tondecomposition into two subsystems, although this property is known to hold fornpure states.
We investigate the question whether the weaker property ofnsubadditivity for pure states with respect to decomposition into more than twonsubsystems holds.
This property would have interesting applications in quantumnchemistry.
We show, however, that it does not hold in general, and provide ancounterexample.n

authors: A.A. Andrianov, F. Cannata, P. Giacconi, A.Yu. Kamenshchik, R. Soldati
title: Symmetries and the cosmological constant puzzle
abstract: We outline the evaluation of the cosmological constant in the framework ofnthe standard field-theoretical treatment of vacuum energy and discuss thenrelation between the vacuum energy problem and the gauge-group spontaneousnsymmetry breaking.
We suggest possible extensions of the t Hooft-Nobbenhuisnsymmetry, in particular, its complexification till duality symmetry and discussnthe compatible implementation on gravity.

We propose to use the discretentime-reflection transform to formulate a framework in which one can eliminatenthe huge contributions of vacuum energy into the effective cosmologicalnconstant and suggest that the breaking of time--reflection symmetry could benresponsible for a small observable value of this constant.n

authors: Guo Lina, Du Jiulin, and Liu Zhipeng
title: The property of kappa-deformed statistics for a relativistic gas in ann  electromagnetic field: kappa parameter and kappa-distribution
abstract: We investigate the physical property of the kappa parameter and thenkappa-distribution in the kappa-deformed statistics, based on Kaniadakisnentropy, for a relativistic gas in an electromagnetic field.

We derive twonrelations for the relativistic gas in the framework of kappa-deformednstatistics, which describe the physical situation represented by thenrelativistic kappa-distribution function, provide a reasonable connectionnbetween the parameter kappa, the temperature four-gradient and the four-vectornpotential gradient, and thus present for the case kappa different from zero anclearly physical meaning.
It is shown that such a physical situation is anmeta-equilibrium state of the system, but has a new physical characteristic.n

authors: Bert Janssen, Yolanda Lozano, Diego Rodriguez-Gomez
title: A KK-monopole giant graviton in AdS_5 x Y_5
abstract: We construct a new giant graviton solution in AdS_5 x Y_5, with Y_5 anquasi-regular Sasaki-Einstein manifold, consisting on a Kaluza-Klein monopolenwrapped around the Y_5 and with its Taub-NUT direction in AdS_5.
We find thatnthis configuration has minimal energy when put in the centre of AdS_5, where itnbehaves as a massless particle.
When we take Y_5 to be S^5, we provide anmicroscopical description in terms of multiple gravitational waves expandingninto the fuzzy S^5 defined as an S^1 bundle over the fuzzy CP^2.
Finally wenprovide a possible field theory dual interpretation of the construction.n

authors: T. Yavorskii, W. Apel, and H.-U. Everts
title: Heisenberg antiferromagnet with anisotropic exchange on the Kagomen  lattice: Description of the magnetic properties of volborthite
abstract: We study the properties of the Heisenberg antiferromagnet with spatiallynanisotropic nearest-neighbour exchange couplings on the kagome net, i.e.
withncoupling J in one lattice direction and couplings J along the other twondirections.
For J/J > 1, this model is believed to describe the magneticnproperties of the mineral volborthite.
In the classical limit, it exhibits twonkinds of ground states: a ferrimagnetic state for J/J < 1/2 and a largenmanifold of canted spin states for J/J > 1/2.
To include quantum effectsnself-consistently, we investigate the Sp(N) symmetric generalisation of thenoriginal SU(2) symmetric model in the large-N limit.
In addition to thendependence on the anisotropy, the Sp(N) symmetric model depends on a parameternkappa that measures the importance of quantum effects.

Our numericalncalculations reveal that in the kappa-J/J plane, the system shows a rich phasendiagram containing a ferrimagnetic phase, an incommensurate phase, and andecoupled chain phase, the latter two with short- and long-range order.
Wencorroborate these results by showing that the boundaries between the variousnphases and several other features of the Sp(N) phase diagram can be determinednby analytical calculations.

Finally, the application of a block-spinnperturbation expansion to the trimerised version of the original spin-1/2 modelnleads us to suggest that in the limit of strong anisotropy, J/J >> 1, thenground state of the original model is a collinearly ordered antiferromagnet,nwhich is separated from the incommensurate state by a quantum phase transition.n

authors: Mark Cropper, Christopher Copperwheat, Kinwah Wu, Roberto Soria
title: On the Nature of Ultra-Luminous X-ray Sources from Optical/IRn  Measurements
abstract: We present a model for the prediction of the optical/infra-red emission fromnULXs.
In the model, ULXs are binary systems with accretion taking place throughnRoche lobe overflow.
We show that irradiation effects and presence of annaccretion disk significantly modify the optical/infrared flux compared tonsingle stars, and also that the system orientation is important.
We includenadditional constraints from the mass transfer rate to constrain the parametersnof the donor star, and to a lesser extent the mass of the BH.
We apply thenmodel to fit photometric data for several ULX counterparts.
We find that mostndonor stars are of spectral type B and are older and less massive than reportednelsewhere, but that no late-type donors are admissable.
The degeneracy of thenacceptable parameter space will be significantly reduced with observations overna wider spectral range, and if time-resolved data become available.n

authors: T.K.T Nguyen, A. Crepieux, T. Jonckheere, A.V. Nguyen, Y. Levinson,n  and T. Martin
title: Dephasing due to a fluctuating fractional quantum Hall edge current
abstract: The dephasing rate of an electron level in a quantum dot, placed next to anfluctuating edge current in the fractional quantum Hall effect, is considered.nUsing perturbation theory, we first show that this rate has an anomalousndependence on the bias voltage applied to the neighboring quantum pointncontact, because of the Luttinger liquid physics which describes the fractionalnHall fluid.
Next, we describe exactly the weak to strong backscatteringncrossover using the Bethe-Ansatz solution.n

authors: Yasha Gindikin and Vladimir A. Sablikov
title: Deformed Wigner crystal in a one-dimensional quantum dot
abstract: The spatial Fourier spectrum of the electron density distribution in a finiten1D system and the distribution function of electrons over single-particlenstates are studied in detail to show that there are two universal features inntheir behavior, which characterize the electron ordering and the deformation ofnWigner crystal by boundaries.
The distribution function has a $delta$-likensingularity at the Fermi momentum $k_F$.
The Fourier spectrum of the densitynhas a step-like form at the wavevector $2k_F$, with the harmonics being absentnor vanishing above this threshold.
These features are found by calculationsnusing exact diagonalization method.
They are shown to be caused by Wignernordering of electrons, affected by the boundaries.
However the common Luttingernliquid model with open boundaries fails to capture these features, because itnoverestimates the deformation of the Wigner crystal.
An improvement of thenLuttinger liquid model is proposed which allows one to describe the abovenfeatures correctly.
It is based on the corrected form of the density operatornconserving the particle number.n

authors: Hirokazu Nishimura
title: Curvature in Synthetic Differential Geometry of Groupoids
abstract: We study the fundamental properties of curvature in groupoids within thenframework of synthetic differential geometry.
As is usual in syntheticndifferential geometry, its combinatorial nature is emphasized.
In particular,nthe classical Bianchi identity is deduced from its combinatorial one.n

authors: Eanna E. Flanagan, Eran Rosenthal
title: Can Gravity Probe B usefully constrain torsion gravity theories?
abstract: In most theories of gravity involving torsion, the source for torsion is thenintrinsic spin of matter.
Since the spins of fermions are normally randomlynoriented in macroscopic bodies, the torsion generated is normally negligible.nHowever, in a recent paper, Mao et al.
point out that there is a class ofntheories in which the angular momentum of macroscopic spinning bodies generatesna significant amount of torsion.

They argue that by the principle of actionnequals reaction, one would expect the angular momentum of test bodies to couplento a background torsion field, and therefore the precession of the GPBngyroscopes should be affected in these theories by the torsion generated by thenEarth.
We show that in fact the principle of action equals reaction does notnapply to these theories.
We examine in detail a generalization of thenHayashi-Shirafuji theory suggested by Mao et al.
callednEinstein-Hayashi-Shirafuji theory.
There are a variety of different versions ofnthis theory, depending on the precise form of the coupling to matter chosen fornthe torsion.
We show that for any coupling to matter that is compatible withnthe spin transport equation postulated by Mao et al., the theory has eithernghosts or an ill-posed initial value formulation.
These theoretical problemsncan be avoided by specializing the parameters of the theory and in additionnchoosing the standard minimal coupling to matter of the torsion tensor.
Thisnyields a consistent theory, but one in which the action equals reactionnprinciple is violated, and in which the angular momentum of the gyroscopes doesnnot couple to the Earths torsion field.
Thus, the Einstein-Hayashi-Shirafujintheory does not predict a detectable torsion signal for Gravity Probe B. Therenmay be other torsion theories which do.n

authors: George A. Elliott and Cristian Ivanescu
title: The classification ofseparable simple C*-algebras which are inductiven  limits of continuous-trace C*-algebraswith spectrum homeomorphic to then  closed interval [0,1]
abstract: A classification is given of certain separable nuclear C*-algebras notnnecessarily of real rank zero, namely, the class of separable simplenC*-algebras which are inductive limits of continuous-trace C*-algebras whosenbuilding blocks have spectrum homeomorphic to the closed interval [0,1], or tona disjoint union of copies of this space.
Also, the range of the invariant isncalculated.n

authors: J.A. Garcia-Barreto, H. Hernandez-Toledo, E. Moreno-Diaz, T.n  Bernal-Marin (IA-UNAM, Mexico) and A.L. Villarreal-Castillo (FC-UNAM, Mexico)
title: U B V R I Photometry of Stellar Structures throughout the Disk of then  Barred Galaxy NGC 3367
abstract: We report new detailed surface U, B, V, R, and I photometry of 81 stellarnstructures in the disk of the barred galaxy NGC 3367.
The images show manyndifferent structures indicating that star formation is going on in the mostnpart of the disk.

NGC 3367 is known to have a very high concentration ofnmolecular gas distribution in the central regions of the galaxy and bipolarnsynchrotron emission from the nucleus with two lobes (at 6 kpc) forming antriple structure similar to a radio galaxy.

We have determined the U, B, V, R,nand I magnitudes and U - B, B - V, U - V, and V - I colors for the centralnregion (nucleus), a region which includes supernovae 2003 AA, and 79 starnassociations throughout NGC 3367.

Estimation of ages of star associations isnvery difficult due to several factors, among them: filling factor, metallicity,nspatial distribution of each structure and the fact that we estimated thenmagnitudes with a circular aperture of 16 pixels in diameter, equivalent ton$6.8sim1.4$ kpc.

However, if the colors derived for NGC 3367 were similar tonthe colors expected of star clusters with theoretical evolutionary star tracksndeveloped for the LMC and had a similar metallicity, NGC 3367 show 51 percentnof the observed structures with age type SWB I (few tens of Myrs), with sevennsources outside the bright surface brightness visible disk of NGC 3367.n

authors: Bernard de Wit
title: BPS Black Holes
abstract: The entropy of BPS black holes in four space-time dimensions is discussednfrom both macroscopic and microscopic points of view.n

authors: Aaron B. Wagner, Pramod Viswanath, and Sanjeev R. Kulkarni
title: A Better Good-Turing Estimator for Sequence Probabilities
abstract: We consider the problem of estimating the probability of an observed stringndrawn i.i.d.
from an unknown distribution.
The key feature of our study is thatnthe length of the observed string is assumed to be of the same order as thensize of the underlying alphabet.
In this setting, many letters are unseen andnthe empirical distribution tends to overestimate the probability of thenobserved letters.
To overcome this problem, the traditional approach tonprobability estimation is to use the classical Good-Turing estimator.
Wenintroduce a natural scaling model and use it to show that the Good-Turingnsequence probability estimator is not consistent.
We then introduce a novelnsequence probability estimator that is indeed consistent under the naturalnscaling model.n

authors: K. Biazzo (1,2), A. Frasca (1), S. Catalano (1), E. Marilli (1) ((1)n  INAF - Catania Astrophysical Observatory, (2) University of Catania)
title: Effective temperature vs line-depth ratio for ELODIE spectra. Gravityn  and rotational velocity effects
abstract: The dependence on the temperature of photospheric line-depth ratios (LDRs) innthe spectral range 6190-6280 A is investigated by using a sample of 174 ELODIEnArchive stellar spectra of luminosity class from V to III.
The rotationalnbroadening effect on LDRs is also studied.
We provide useful calibrations ofneffective temperature versus LDRs for giant and main sequence stars withn3800<Teff<6000 K and vsini in the range 0-30 km/s.

We found that, with thenexception of very few line pairs, LDRs, measured at a spectral resolution asnhigh as 42000, depend on vsini and that, by neglecting the rotationalnbroadening effect, one can mistake the Teff determination of 100 K in the worstncases.n

authors: Thibault Damour
title: Chaos and Symmetry in String Cosmology
abstract: We review the recently discovered interplay between chaos and symmetry in thengeneral inhomogeneous solution of many string-related Einstein-matter systemsnin the vicinity of a cosmological singularity.

ThenBelinsky-Khalatnikov-Lifshitz-type chaotic behaviour is found, for manynEinstein-matter models (notably those related to the low-energy limit ofnsuperstring theory and M-theory), to be connected with certainn(infinite-dimensional) hyperbolic Kac-Moody algebras.

In particular, thenbilliard chambers describing the asymptotic cosmological behaviour of purenEinstein gravity in spacetime dimension d+1, or the metric-three-form system ofn11-dimensional supergravity, are found to be identical to the Weyl chambers ofnthe Lorentzian Kac-Moody algebras AE_d, or E_{10}, respectively.
This suggestsnthat these Kac-Moody algebras are hidden symmetries of the correspondingnmodels.

There even exists some evidence of a hidden equivalence between thengeneral solution of the Einstein-three-form system and a null geodesic in theninfinite dimensional coset space E_{10} / K(E_{10}), where K(E_{10}) is thenmaximal compact subgroup of E_{10}.n

authors: James S. Ulvestad, Jenny E. Greene, and Luis C. Ho
title: Radio Emission from the Intermediate-mass Black Hole in the Globularn  Cluster G1
abstract: We have used the Very Large Array (VLA) to search for radio emission from thenglobular cluster G1 (Mayall-II) in M31.
G1 has been reported by Gebhardt et al.nto contain an intermediate-mass black hole (IMBH) with a mass of ~2 x 10^4nsolar masses.
Radio emission was detected within an arcsecond of the clusterncenter with an 8.4 GHz power of 2 x 10^{15} W/Hz.

The radio/X-ray ratio of G1nis a few hundred times higher than that expected for a high-mass X-ray binarynin the cluster center, but is consistent with the expected value for accretionnonto an IMBH with the reported mass.
A pulsar wind nebula is also a possiblencandidate for the radio and X-ray emission from G1; future high-sensitivitynVLBI observations might distinguish between this possibility and an IMBH.

Ifnthe radio source is an IMBH, and similar accretion and outflow processes occurnfor hypothesized ~ 1000-solar-mass black holes in Milky Way globular clusters,nthey are within reach of the current VLA and should be detectable easily by thenExpanded VLA when it comes on line in 2010.n

authors: M. T. Yamashita, T. Frederico and Lauro Tomio
title: Trajectory of neutron$-$neutron$-^{18}C$ excited three-body state
abstract: The trajectory of the first excited Efimov state is investigated by using anrenormalized zero-range three-body model for a system with two bound and onenvirtual two-body subsystems.
The approach is applied to $n-n-^{18}$C, where then$n-n$ virtual energy and the three-body ground state are kept fixed.
It isnshown that such three-body excited state goes from a bound to a virtual statenwhen the $n-^{18}$C binding energy is increased.
Results obtained for then$n-^{19}$C elastic cross-section at low energies also show dominance of ann$S-$matrix pole corresponding to a bound or virtual Efimov state.
It is alsonpresented a brief discussion of these findings in the context of ultracold atomnphysics with tunable scattering lengths.n

authors: Charles Bordenave and Giovanni Luca Torrisi
title: Large deviations of Poisson cluster processes
abstract: In this paper we prove scalar and sample path large deviation principles forna large class of Poisson cluster processes.
As a consequence, we provide anlarge deviation principle for ergodic Hawkes point processes.n

authors: Earl T. Campbell
title: Distributed quantum information processing with minimal local resources
abstract: We present a protocol for growing graph states, the resource for one-waynquantum computing, when the available entanglement mechanism is highlynimperfect.
The distillation protocol is frugal in its use of ancilla qubits,nrequiring only a single ancilla qubit when the noise is dominated by one Paulinerror, and two for a general noise model.
The protocol works with such scarcenlocal resources by never post-selecting on the measurement outcomes ofnpurification rounds.
We find that such a strategy causes fidelity to follow anbiased random walk, and that a target fidelity is likely to be reached morenrapidly than for a comparable post-selecting protocol.
An analysis is presentednof how imperfect local operations limit the attainable fidelity.
For example, ansingle Pauli error rate of 20% can be distilled down to $sim 10$ times thenimperfection in local operations.n

authors: Hannes Leeb, Benedikt M. Poetscher
title: Sparse Estimators and the Oracle Property, or the Return of Hodgesn  Estimator
abstract: We point out some pitfalls related to the concept of an oracle property asnused in Fan and Li (2001, 2002, 2004) which are reminiscent of the well-knownnpitfalls related to Hodges estimator.
The oracle property is often anconsequence of sparsity of an estimator.

We show that any estimator satisfyingna sparsity property has maximal risk that converges to the supremum of the lossnfunction; in particular, the maximal risk diverges to infinity whenever thenloss function is unbounded.
For ease of presentation the result is set in thenframework of a linear regression model, but generalizes far beyond thatnsetting.
In a Monte Carlo study we also assess the extent of the problem innfinite samples for the smoothly clipped absolute deviation (SCAD) estimatornintroduced in Fan and Li (2001).

We find that this estimator can perform rathernpoorly in finite samples and that its worst-case performance relative tonmaximum likelihood deteriorates with increasing sample size when the estimatornis tuned to sparsity.n

authors: Yuri Martinez-Raton
title: Capillary ordering and layering transitions in two-dimensional hard-rodn  fluids
abstract: In this article we calculate the surface phase diagram of a two-dimensionalnhard-rod fluid confined between two hard lines.
In a first stage we study thensemi-infinite system consisting of an isotropic fluid in contact with a singlenhard line.
We have found complete wetting by the columnar phase at thenwall-isotropic fluid interface.

When the fluid is confined between two hardnwalls, capillary columnar ordering occurs via a first-order phase transition.nFor higher chemical potentials the system exhibits layering transitions evennfor very narrow slits (near the one-dimensional limit).

The theoretical modelnused was a density-functional theory based on the Fundamental-MeasurenFunctional applied to a fluid of hard rectangles in the restricted-orientationnapproximation (Zwanzig model).

The results presented here can be checkednexperimentally in two-dimensional granular media made of rods, where verticalnmotions induced by an external source and excluded volume interactions betweennthe grains allow the system to explore those stationary states whichnentropically maximize packing configurations.
